Posts.Title: the emotional toll of hair loss Mandy41 Phebe38

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 12:11AM meliaanne wrote: Hi 3boys4me, I am so sorry you are in such distress. It is a shock to see the scar, though it wasn't as bad as I feared. I view it now as a battle scar, a badge of courage. I miss my breast, of course; the best part of my life was raising my 3 kids, and I nursed them. I am used to it now, 8 months out, and don't even really notice it. I too pray for peace for you. It will come. Be kind to yourself. You are still in shock. Melia
Posts.Title: accepting body after surgery 3boys4me janniexy

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 07:30AM meliaanne wrote: I had a big problem with fluid retention, mainly in my legs and feet. I was up to 120 mg of lasix a day, now seven months out and still on 80mg. My crazy onc said he had never seen it before as a result of taxol, ran all kinds of tests to be sure nothing else was wrong. I knew all along it was the taxol. Surprisingly, what really helped was walking, even though I had no energy and it was the last thing I wanted to do. My daughter is a vet, and she told me that when horses had edema, they are walked, so I figured, what the heck. Even just moving around every hour was a big help. I am trying to wean off the lasix, but even at 80 mg, I feel it a bit in my legs by the end of the day. And I did gain about 10 lbs, but it all came right off. Good luck, it will end one day and you WILL feel better.
Posts.Title: Taxotere weight gain and fluid retention chancleta duffyzmom

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 12:34PM meliaanne wrote: Hi Passenger, I had 34 nodes removed with my mastectomy. The pain was very bearable. I took vicadin, and that was fine .... but there are lots of other meds if that doesn't work for you. I think there was more discomfort below my shoulder (the surgeon really dug around!) than anywhere else, and even that was not bad. And I am a sissy. Â Good luck, and ask more questions as you have them. Melia
Posts.Title: more surgery Passenger59 sue_m

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2007 08:11PM meliaanne wrote: Oh Sweetie, I so remember that feeling. I am just at a year past diagnosis, and I am fine. I had surgery, six months of chemo, hair is coming back ... you will make it. You are scared and shocked. You have found the best place to be. Ask questions, talk to us, post as often as you want to. We are here, and we will help you. This board was, and is, my safe place. Just know you will be ok. You can do this. Melia
Posts.Title: Numb DAnne iodine

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2007 05:28AM meliaanne wrote: Hi Sue, I had severe edema and am sure it was from taxol. My legs, ankles, and feet were swollen from about late June to mid August. I finished 12 weekly taxols on July 5. I am still on 120 mg lasix (along with potassium) but am just this week experimenting with cutting it to 80. I agree with Carol, exercise really helped. It is miserably uncomforable, and I really sympathise with you, but it will eventually go away. I would ask for more lasix though. My dr still contends it wasn't from the chemo. Yeah, right. The good news is that I am now four months out from treatment, feel great, just a bit stiff. My energy level is good, and I am back to doing everything I did before. You will feel better too. Good luck. Melia
Posts.Title: Terribly Swollen Feet & Ankles SueB46 meliaanne

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2007 07:42AM - edited Jun 25, 2008 09:45AM by meliaanne I start with a/c on wed the 17th. Scared and upset, but I felt that way walking into biopsy, surgery, oncologist ... I am ok once I have to handle something, but kind of a sissy beforehand. I have tapes, magazines, water, candy, crackers, biotene ...will be glad to have one behind me!

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2007 11:51AM meliaanne wrote: I have had more trouble dealing with hair loss than any other aspect of this .... at least once I accepted that I had to deal with bc at all. I think it's so hard. I wear a wig to work everyday, and it's lovely, but I am bald and I look awful when I take it off. And the funny thing is, I never had much confidence in my looks. But I always loved my hair. And my breasts. Now I have one breast and a bald head. Jeez.

Posts.Content: meliaanne wrote: This thread has been so helpful. I have lymphedema, wear a compression sleeve and gauntlet. I am new to all this. I finished a series of appts/massages with my lymphedema specialist. I am trying to be thorough with the massaging every day, but am having trouble reaching my back. Any tips?Â  Burt and White's book suggests a paint roller, which I have tried, but am not too happy with how it does .... I don't have anyone to help do it, so have to figure it out!Â  I figure some of you experienced ladies might have tips? Thanks so much, Melia Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: meliaanne wrote: Hi all, I am sure you have answered this many times, but here goes. I had a left mastectomy on Dec 11 and have healed ok. I am flying cross country in a couple of months. My onc seems to have a pretty carefree approach to lymphodema, which I haven't yet developed. Where do you get compression sleeves? Should I talk to the dr, or so you get them at pharmacies? thanks, Melia Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: newbie; question re flying meliaanne meliaanne

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 07:05PM meliaanne wrote: Hi, I had chemo last January through July. I am doing great, hair growing back, loving life. I did work all thru chemo, but I have a desk job, so it was doable. I had a 4 cm idc, no nodes. I did three months of ac, three months of taxol.Â  I was terrified, do not want to minimize in any way what you are all going through. I just want you to know that you can do it. I never told anyone at work about my bc except my boss. One of the reasons I could pull it off was that I bought a great wig, which I wore everyday for 10 months. It is a Sky by Noriko, Ginger color. If any of you want it, I would be happy to mail it to you. Just know that I wore it a lot. I thought it looked great til theÂ  end. PM me and I will send it to you. I do have a big head, so if you are tiny, it is probably too big for you .... but it worked. I am active in the Jan 07 thread. I hope you find the solace and comfort here that I have found. I am such a private person that very few people, outside my family, know of my cancer. I was never a bit ashamed, just didn't want to talk about it to outsiders. Know that there is no right or wrong way to do this journey. But my Jan 07 sisters were, and are, so key to my well-being. Big hugs to all of you. I will help you any way I can. Just pm me with questions ... and let me know if you want the wig. Melia
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2007 05:35AM meliaanne wrote: Hi Ladies, I happened upon this thread, and want to tell you that you can do it. Today is my one yr anniv of the mastectomy. I did six months of chemo, 4 ac, 12 weekly taxols. It was hard, but I worked the entire time (I have a desk job, so it was doable). I was mostly very tired, mouth sores, and of course, bald. But my hair is coming back nicely, I feel pretty much back to normal, and I honestly believe if I can do it, anyone can. I didn't have a port either, and I was glad about that. the less surgeries, the better, in my opinion. I do have good veins. Just take it in baby steps, have faith in your strength and decisions, and know that you will get through it and will get your life back. I am on the Jan 07 board, and it was (and is) an enormous source of info, encouragement, and a very safe place to vent. God Bless. Stay strong, and know that you are loved. Melia
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: meliaanne wrote: Hi All, I have had mild lymphedema for over a year, the result of having axillary node removal, 34 (!) nodes. I have been able to control it with the sleeve, gauntlet, massage, and have access to a good certified therapist. However, I was hit with a nasty bout of cellulitis this week. I went back and read LindaLou's post about her experience (LindaLou, you have helped me in ways you will never know, both with this and with my whining when first diagnosed with lymphedema. You too, Binney.) Â Anyway, after three iv treatments and still on oral antibiotics, I am much better. The arm still looks gnarly, but the pain is gone, swelling is subsiding, redness dissipating, etc. My concerns are regarding what to do now. Â First, I am more likely to have this happen again now that it has happened once?Â  How and when do I transition back to wearing the sleeve?Â  I thought I was being really vigilant re scratches, etc, and cannot see any skin break in that arm. This hit me out ofÂ nowhere, while I was across country on a business trip, naturally. Any advice other than normal vigilance about avoiding this happening again?Â  I am going to call the lymphedema therapist with these questions too, but you ladies are at least as knowledgeable as she is. Also, when first diagnosed, I asked about bike riding and was told it was fine. This is a real love of mine. We often ride on weekends, nothing too strenuous, about 20 miles or so. I had gone on a ride the day before the cellulitis hit me. Any opinions on bike riding? I am talking bicycles, not motor bikes. Thanks in advance for the help. I don't remember being that sick or in that much pain. I want to avoid it if I can. Hugs, Melia Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: cellulitis aftermath meliaanne Binney4

Posts.Content: May 22, 2009 03:38PM meliaanne wrote: Thanks for the feedback, Kira and Binney.Â  I felt kind of punk on the way to the airport, but it didn't register that it had anything to do with my arm. By the time I got to the hotel and took off the sleeve, my arm was hard, hot, and red. I started on the antibiotics that I carry with me, and the next morning called my pt. She said I had to see a dr that day. I was flying home anyway, went straight to urgent care, and the dr gave me the first of three iv antibiotics. I had three daily, the last one last night. Now it's very itchy. Is that normal for this problem?Â  It's much much much better, though, still looks red and blotchy, but no pain. So I should start wearing the sleeve again now, or wait until it is all cleared up?Â  If I had caught it earlier, would the oral antibiotics potentially clear it up, or are iv's always needed?Â  I am worried about what happens if this occurs during a camping trip, overseas trip, etc. It got so bad so fast! Melia
Posts.Title: cellulitis aftermath meliaanne Binney4
